messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 45 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Finite-valued Streaming String Transducers

Paper Abstract: Abstract A transducer is finite-valued if for some bound kùëòk, it maps any given input to at most kùëòk outputs. For classical, one-way transducers, it is known since the 80s that finite valuedness entails decidability of the equivalence problem. This decidability result is in contrast to the general case, which makes finite-valued transducers very attractive. For classical transducers it is also known that finite valuedness is decidable and that any kùëòk-valued finite transducer can be decomposed as a union of kùëòk single-valued finite transducers. In this paper, we extend the above results to copyless streaming string transducers (SSTs), answering questions raised by Alur and Deshmukh in 2011. SSTs strictly extend the expressiveness of one-way transducers via additional variables that store partial outputs. We prove that any kùëòk-valued SST can be effectively decomposed as a union of kùëòk (single-valued) deterministic SSTs. As a corollary, we obtain equivalence of SSTs and two-way transducers in the finite-valued case (those two models are incomparable in general). Another corollary is an elementary upper bound for checking equivalence of finite-valued SSTs. The latter problem was already known to be decidable, but the proof complexity was unknown (it relied on Ehrenfeucht‚Äôs conjecture). Finally, our main result is that finite valuedness of SSTs is decidable. The complexity is PSpace, and even PTime when the number of variables is fixed.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 45 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 45"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "A proof of Ehrenfeucht‚Äôs conjecture",
        "Expressiveness of streaming string transducers",
        "Streaming transducers for algorithmic verification of single-pass list-processing programs",
        "Streaming tree transducers",
        "Nondeterministic streaming string transducers",
        "Composing copyless streaming string transducers",
        "Regular transformations of infinite strings",
        "Automatic structures",
        "The hilbert method for transducer equivalence",
        "Transducers of polynomial growth",
        "On the growth rates of polyregular functions",
        "String-to-string interpretations with polynomial-size output",
        "Graph Structure and Monadic Second-Order Logic - A Language-Theoretic Approach, volume 138 of Encyclopedia of mathematics and its applications",
        "The equivalence of finite valued transducers (on HDT0L languages) is decidable",
        "On reversible transducers",
        "Aperiodic string transducers",
        "Etude structurelle des transducteurs de norme born√©e",
        "Optimization of string transducers",
        "MSO definable string transductions and two-way finite-state transducers",
        "A regular and complete notion of delay for streaming string transducers",
        "Copyful streaming string transducers",
        "Multi-tape one-way nonwriting automata",
        "Equivalence of infinite systems of equations in free groups and semigroups to finite subsystems",
        "The complexity of decision problems for finite-turn multicounter machines",
        "A note on finite-valued and finitely ambiguous transducers",
        "D√©cidabilit√© par automate fini",
        "The unsolvability of the equivalence problem for e-free NGSM‚Äôs with unary input (output) alphabet and applications",
        "Un algorithme calculant le cardinal, fini ou infini, des demi-groupes de matrices",
        "A Ramsey theorem for finite monoids",
        "Do rational equivalence relations have regular cross-sections?",
        "Automatic presentations of structures",
        "Streaming string transducers (internship report)",
        "On finite semigroups of matrices",
        "Equivalence of finite-valued streaming string transducers is decidable",
        "Outils et r√©sultats pour les transducteurs boustroph√©dons",
        "Systems of word equations, polynomials and linear algebra: A new approach",
        "A construction on finite automata that has remained hidden",
        "On the decidability of bounded valuedness for transducers",
        "On the decomposition of k-valued rational relations",
        "Equivalence of finite-valued tree transducers is decidable",
        "The reduction of two-way automata to one-way automata",
        "Decomposing finite-valued transducers and deciding their equivalence",
        "Decomposing a k-valued transducer into k unambiguous ones",
        "On the degree of ambiguity of finite automata",
        "On the decidability of the valuedness problem for two-way finite transducers"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 45 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Finite-valued Streaming String Transducers, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
